title: More Victorian types
content:
Can anyone put a name to these letters? I know I've seen the first one before but I can't think where. I've looked at Solotype and Spiece Graphics and Nick's Fonts and have struck out.   
   
 ![penny type 1](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225233im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/49991.jpg)   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225233im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/49992.jpg)   
 ![nickel](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225233im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/49993.jpg)
author: ahleman

comments.content:
Middle one is a Venitian of some kind, although a really funky cut with those concave serifs. Cleaner, more regularized digitizations include [ITC Golden](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225233/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/golden-type-ef/golden-type-original/testdrive.html) and [Nicolas Jenson](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225233/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/spiecegraphics/nicolas-jenson-sg/regular/testdrive.html) from Spiece.   
   
For the last one, try something from Dan Solo. [Excelsis](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225233/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/solotype/excelsis/?PREFS_SET%5BRenderSize%5D=36&PREFS_SET%5BRenderString%5D=Best+5c.+cigar) is a decent match, but you might be able to get even closer.   
   
The first one has me stumped. It resembles [Brittanic](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225233/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/britannic/medium/testdrive.html?s=DROP+ONE+CENT+IN+THE+SLOT&p=36), but is obviously funkier. G'luck!
The first one has some similarities with Globe Extended. I could swear I've seen it somewhere. It's driving me crazy!

[McKenna Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225233/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/mckenna-handletter-nf/mc-kenna-handletter-nf-bold/testdrive.html?s=6+wins+1+cigar&p=48) gives a very similar feeling to the second example, even though it's not an exact character match. I have the same font with the name "Colwell".
The first is like a hybrid between Globe and good ol' [Grant Antique](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516225233/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/48686.html).
